oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photographs and captions from Miss Edith Scott's Memory Book, started July 1957. Her ancestors included the Scott, Deaderick, Crozier, Ramsey, Anderson and Alexander families. Francis Alexander Ramsey Scott (1827-1909) married Margaretta Frances Deaderick (1833-1909) in 1857. They were the parents of eleven children, including daughter Miss Edith Scott (1878-1971). Caption information appears below in the Full Text field. Roscoe C. d'Armand.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: We have just seen that my great-grandfather, James Scott, Sr.., was with John Sevier in fighting the Indians, and as he was a good age at the Battle of Kings Mountain, he could have been in that engagement, but we could not prove that he fought at that time. My cousin, Roscoe C. d'Armand, a direct descendent of James Scott, Sr., is a wonderful genealogist, and he wrote me June 20, 1961 - "James Scott, Sr., served with North Carolina troops during the Revolutionary War from Captain Vail's Company, Second Regiment 1777; and again in Captain Bailey's Company 10th Regiment, for a period of 12 months from August 1, 1782. Apparently ancester James served first as a lad of 17 and again after he reached manhood and shortly before he married. It has been a long trail and a long search, done most of the time in darkness with no assurance whatever save legends that survived. Apparently he did serve with Sevier and Landon Carter, since their names both appear on his voucher". Again, August 10, 1961, he sent me all I need for a supplemental DAR paper on James Scott Sr.. JAMES SCOTT, Sr. served during the Revolutionary War, as a private from August 1, 1782, for a period of 12 months; and again as a private in Vail's Company, 2nd Regiment, from 1777 to November 1777, both in North Carolina troops. He afterward served with John Sevier in his war against the Indians and achieved the rank of Captain and then Colonel. Department of Archives and History, North Carolina Records, page 1153: 2nd Regiment Muster and page 1165: 10th Regiment Muster. Inid, Treasurer's Papers, Rev. Vochers No. 3344, June 12, 1783: The auditors for the counties of Washington and Sullivan certify that James Scott is allowed 9 pound specie as per voucher 12th of June 1783: By E. Williams - Landon Carter. John Sevier, Sec." My cousin writes "our Colonel Scott's military service is without question and the proof is there". I am indeed most happy to know my great-grandfather was a true patriot and fought for his country.
